security: This material contains information affecting the National Defense of the United States within the meaning of the Espionage Laws, Title 18, U.S.C Secs 793 and 794, the transmission or revelation of which in any manner to an unauthorized person is prohibited by law.
summary: In mid-September 1962, Tran Kim Tuyen proposed to Huang Tien-Mai a joint South Vietnamese and Nationalist Chinese intelligence operation in Laos due to the deteriorating situation and potential break in relations with Laos. Huang Tien-Mai concurred but needed approval from the Chinese Nationalist government.
summary_one_paragraph: On September 25, 1962, the CIA distributed an information report detailing a proposal made in mid-September 1962 by Tran Kim Tuyen, Chief of the Presidential Security Service of South Vietnam, to Huang Tien-Mai, Chief of the Chinese Nationalist National Security Bureau Intelligence Station in Saigon, to conduct joint intelligence operations in Laos. Tuyen suggested establishing intelligence stations on the border between Laos and South Vietnam and within Laos to support Vietnamese/Nationalist Chinese agent operations, citing the deteriorating situation in Laos. Huang agreed in principle but communicated that he needed approval from the Chinese Nationalist government before proceeding, and on September 19, 1962, he telegraphed his headquarters in Taipei for approval.
title: Information Report
recipient: STATE/INR DIA ARMY/ACSI NAVY AIR JCS SECDEF NSA NIC AID USIA OC.I ONE OCR STATE DIR ORR.
